results.title: Othello
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Television Shakespeare Series”.
Featuring Anthony Hopkins as Othello, Bob Hoskins as Iago and Penelope Wilton as Desdemona. Jealousy and treachery fill this play as Iago, ensign to Othello, annoyed by Casio’s recent promotion as the Moor’s lieutenant, decides upon revenge. He sets out to destroy Othello’s relationship with Desdemona by telling her father that Othello has raped Desdemona; and the, when this falsehood has been overcome, spreads the myth of Casio and Desdemona’s love for each other. Iago’s treachery is eventually exposed but only after Othello has murdered Desdemona and then stabbed himself.

results.title: Othello
results.headline_credit: France, Italy, Morocco and United States of America, 1951
results.brief_description: When a secret marriage is planned between Othello, a Moorish general, and Desdemona, the daughter of Senator Brabantio, her old suitor Roderigo takes it hard. He allies himself with Iago, who has his own grudge against Othello, and the two conspire to bring Othello down. When their first plan, to have him accused of witchcraft, fails, they plant evidence intended to make him believe Desdemona is unfaithful.

results.title: Othello
results.creator_credit: John Brabourne, Anthony Havelock-Allan and Stuart Burge
results.brief_description: National Theatre of Great Britain’s stage production of William Shakespeare’s play. Features Laurence Olivier, Maggie Smith, Derek Jacobi and Frank Finlay. Although the lighting is very dark at times making the action hard to discern, this dramatisation is very powerful and moving.

results.title: Othello
results.creator_credit: Oliver Parker, David Barron, Luc Roeg, Imminent Films and Dakota Films
results.brief_description: Othello: an intoxicating mix of love, sexual passion and the deadly power of jealousy. Riddled with jealousy and twisted with racial hatred, Iago (Kenneth Branagh) schemes and plots his way to torturing the love of Othello (Laurence Fishburne) and Desdemona (Irene Jacob). In a visually stunning and superbly acted masterpiece, Othello tells the most passionate tale of love and betrayal of all time.

results.title: Otello
results.creator_credit: Franco Zeffirelli, Yoram Globus, Menahem Golan, Cannon Productions and Golan-Globus Productions
results.brief_description: Otello, the opera by Giuseppe Verdi, libretto by Arigo Boito, based on Shakespeare’s play and adapted for the screen by Franco Zeffirelli and Masolino D’Amico. Magnificent camera work by Ennio Guarnieri, in majestic natural surroundings with splendidly rendered music distinguishes this retelling of Venice’s Moor governor of Cyprus. Otello (Placido Domingo) has the poison of jealousy infused in his veins by his friend, Iago (Justino Diaz). The latter, by means of manipulating with a handkerchief once given as a love token gift, has Otello kill his beloved wife Desdomena (Katia Ricciarelli), then Iago and finally himself. All this whilst young Cassio (Desdomena’s supposed but innocent lover) watches what havoc men wreak on their souls and bodies when passion has relieved them of reason. Performers include Petra Malakova, Urbano Barberini, Sergio Nicolai, Edwin Francis, Massimo Foschi and features the Orchestra and Chorus of Teatro Scala of Milan, music produced and conducted by Lorin Maazel. Sung in Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Ost offic
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, ACMI and Helen Grace
results.brief_description: Helen Grace reworks images of a disused rural post office and repurposes found footage in this poetic meditation on the fragility of civic space.

results.title: Ossessione
results.creator_credit: Luchino Visconti, Libero Solaroli and ICI (GB)
results.brief_description: A restless wife, Giovanna, meets Gino, a rough and handsome vagabond. Their passionate affair leads to the murder of Giovanna’s boorish husband. Can a strong and sensual affair survive the guilt? Adapted from James M. Cain’s classic novel “The Postman always rings twice”, Ossessione is a dark and provocative drama of sexual tension. It heralded a new era of Italian cinema, establishing Luchino Visconti as a leading and controversial exponent of Neorealism. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Osmose
results.brief_description:
Osmose (1995) is an immersive virtual environment with real-time display of 3D computer graphics and interactive 3D localized sound. The interface consists of a head-mounted display and real-time motion tracking based on breath and balance. There are a dozen world-spaces in Osmose, most based on metaphorical aspects of nature. Immersants are able to journey anywhere within these worlds, as well as hover in the ambiguous transition areas.

The first realm encountered is a three-dimensional Cartesian grid which functions as an orientation space. With the immersant’s first breaths, this grid gives way to a clearing, surrounded by forest. It is possible to enter the clearing’s single tree and the interior of its leaves, float through the never-ending forest, or descend into subterranean depths among translucent roots and rocks. One can also sink through the pond into an oceanic abyss, or rise above the clearing into cloud. Two additional realms function as conceptual parentheses around the work: the substratum Code located below the underearth, which contains much of the actual software used to create the work; and the superstratum Text, located above the cloud, consisting of excerpts of relevant texts on technology, the body and nature.

The sounds in Osmose were sampled from a male and female voice uttering phonetics, then digitally processed and localized in three-dimensions. The sound is generated on the fly, in real time, responding like the visuals to changes in the immersant’s head and body position, direction and speed. After fifteen minutes of immersion, a symbolic life-world appears and then irretrievably recedes, bringing the session to an end.

Osmose was so named for “osmosis” from “osmos” (Greek) “to push”; a biological process involving passage from one side of a semi-permeable cellular membrane to another. Osmose, as metaphor, is about longing: for transcendence of difference through mutual absorption; for dissolution of boundaries; for overcoming estrangement between self and other; for the soulful intermingling of self and world.

(NOTE: This text is from an artist statement composed by Char Davies for the Transfigure exhibition)
